results.title: Mark (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
A quadriplegic boy. One of a series of films created originally for day-time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies.

results.title: Marjorie Barnard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Historical novelist, Marjorie Barnard recalls priceless memories of fellow writers who “peopled her world”, including Xavier Herbert, Vance and Nettie Palmer and Frank Dalby Davison.

results.title: Marius and Jeanette
results.creator_credit: Robert Guediguian, Gilles Sandoz, La Sept Cinema, Cie and Agat Films
results.brief_description: Jeanette (Ariane Ascaride) is a middle-aged cashier, struggling on a low wage in the new global economy and trying to raise her two children as best she can. Marius (Gerrard Meylan) is a security guard who falls in love with the fiery Jeanette but is uncertain if the traumas of his past will ruin the chance for happiness between them. Filmed in the industrial city of Marseilles, this deeply humanistic film reinstates the provincial working class as the subject of French cinema, examining the condition of working people in the post-Soviet era of globalisation and economic rationalism. Retreating from the radical aesthetics of the post-68 generation, “Marius and Jeannette” instead takes its inspiration from the humanist realist traditions of early French cinema and the social realism associated with the English cinema of Ken Loach and Mark Leigh. Family, commitment and trust are celebrated in this film, as is tolerance, and political and communal responsibility. The acting of Ascaride and Meylan is first rate, as it is with the excellent supporting cast. Filmed in the proletariat sections of the city, this film is also a loving tribute to the history of struggle in Marseilles. In the age of ironic detachment or extravagant violence, “Marius and Jeannette” is a fin-de-siecle film that argues for engagement and for tenderness. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Marius
results.brief_description:
Marius, who works in his father’s dockside cafe in Marseilles, is set to marry Fanny, his childhood sweetheart. But the call of the sea is too strong for him, and he joins the merchant navy, unware that Fanny is pregnant. The film succeeds best in his portrayal of the little people of Marseilles, their humour and accents. This is the first film of Pagnol’s ‘Marseille trilogy’, followed by ‘Fanny’ (1932) and ‘Cesar’ (1936) [*=Held in our collection].

Credits: Producer, Bob T. Kane ; director, Alexandre Korda ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Ted Pahle ; music, Francis Gromon.
Cast: Raimu, Pierre Fresnay, Fernand Charpin, Orane Demazis, Alida Rouffe, Robert Vattier, Marcel Maupi.

results.title: Marionettes: construction and manipulation
results.brief_description: A detailed description of the construction of Bobo, a glove puppet, at the Universal School of Handicraft Marionette Theatre. When Bobo is finished and dressed, and his controls for manipulation attached, Mrs. Goedeler demonstrates how Bobo is manipulated. He is seen in action with a trained seal.

results.title: Marion of Colignan
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marion Peters loves living on the land. Despite having the opportunity of establishing a life in the city, she returned to her hometown to raise a family with her husband Geoff on a 12-hectare organic farm that they developed from scratch. Having overcome droughts, hailstorms and the large financial strain of maintaining a farm, Marion feels that things are finally looking up, with a bumper harvest of apples and promising yields of avocadoes and lemons. Marion is heavily involved in giving back to her community, pivotal in fundraising and ensuring community activities are maintained in a small town with a small population. She believes that it is vital for locals to stay involved and active within their own community.

results.title: Mario: The Philippines
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation and Soerabaia Pictures
results.brief_description: Study of Mario, a Filipino boy aged about eight years how has left school and works to help with the family income. Notes the life style of the people, the market, the role of the children and a causeway built for the locals by Australian engineers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: South Australian Film Corporation and Soerabaia Pictures

results.title: Mario Kart 64
results.brief_description:
Three… Two… One… GO! The signal light changes and you drop the pedal to the metal. Take on up to three friends in the split-screen VS games, or race solo in the Mario GP. Tell your friends to bring it on in the highly competitive Battle mode. Advanced features allow you to race with your “Ghost”. The driving data from your best run appears as a transparent character on the screen. No longer must you simply race against the clock — you can actually race against yourself!

  • Save your hottest Ghost data to a portable N64 Controller Pak!

  • Collect multiple power-up items!

  • Twenty different courses — 4 Cups with 4 courses each and 4 special Battle mode courses!

  • Everyone’s favorite characters are back and gorgeously rendered, including two new additions, Donkey Kong and Wario!

constellations_other.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_other.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

constellations_other.name: Lois Weber and the split-screen
constellations_other.description: Lois Weber was the third filmmaker to use split screens to show simultaneous action, helping establish it as part of cinematic language, particularly its use in thrillers. It's since been taken to extremes by auteurs and videogames.

results.title: Marine sand animals
results.brief_description: A simple ecological study of common animals whose structure and habits enable them to live in the sand of the sea-shore or the sea-bed. The following animals are seen: Astropecten burrowing and turning over; the heart-urchin burrowing (time-lapse under-water cinematography); the weever fish; the plaice; the masked crab burrowing; various worms either actively burrowing or living in tubes and collecting their food. The whole series is related to the fall and rise of the tide.
